The Jewel of Algebra

Posted on October 30, 2014

Richard P. Feynman calls it our jewel – \[ e^{i\theta} = cos(\theta) + i \ sin(\theta) \]

I can easily type mathematical expressions in my blog posts and this post is dedicated to this revelation! :-D

And a fact just for fun –

The following holds \[ \sum\limits_{i = 1}^{n} (x_i - y_i)^2 \geq \sum\limits_{i=1}^{n} (x_i - z_i)^2 \] when \[ x_1 \geq x_2 \geq x_3 ... \geq x_n \] \[ y_1 \leq y_2 \leq y_3 ... \leq y_n \] and \(z\) is a permutation of \(y\).

Still figuring out.
